An easy synthesis of a novel solid catalyst based on chitosan grafted with phosphonium ionic liquid (CS@PIL) supporting bismuth (Bi) was carried out through a two-step process. In the first step, chitosan was modified with phosphonium ionic liquid (PIL), and in the second step, Bi(III) ions were coordinated to the chelating groups on the solid support. The resulting materials were characterized using various techniques, including FTIR and solid-state NMR spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction, ICP-MS, and thermogravimetry. It was found that the desired products of Biginelli condensation couldn't be obtained when Bi(III) was supported on native chitosan due to the reactivity of its NH2 groups with the aldehyde reactant In turn, the modified CS@PIL@Bi catalyst exhibited remarkable efficiency and recyclability as a heterogeneous catalyst in the one-step Pietro Biginelli condensation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biginelli reaction Quaternary phosphonium Chitosan Bismuth Multicomponent reaction Dihydropyrimidinone heterocycles Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction The Biginelli condensation is a one-pot multicomponent reaction (MCR) that has attracted considerable attention in the field of organic synthesis, due to its versatility and the simplicity of its reaction conditions. It involves the use of aldehydes, 1,3-ketoesters, and urea or thiourea to form multifunctional dihydropyrimidinones (DHPMs) and related heterocyclic compounds via cycloaddition [1,2]. The reaction was first discovered in 1893 and involved a reaction between benzaldehydes, urea, and ethyl acetoacetate, catalyzed by hydrochloric acid in ethanol [3]. In recent years, Biginelli compounds, particularly DHPMs, have gained significant attention in the pharmaceutical industry due to their diverse biological and pharmacological properties [4] including anti-inflammatory [5], antimicrobial [6], antioxidant-antibacterial [7], antihypertensive [8], anti-VIH [9], anti-SARS [10], and anticancer activity [11]. As a consequence, many catalytic methodologies have been developed to improve the production of the functional DHPMs. These methodologies include homogeneous catalysts such as Brønsted acids (e.g., HCl [12] and chiral phosphoric acid [13,14]), bases (e.g., NaOH [15] and t-BuOK [16]), and Lewis acids (e.g., AlCl3 [17], Fe(OTs)3·6H2O [18], ZnCl2 [19], BiCl3 [20], Bi(NO3)3 [21] and Bi(OTf)3 [22]), as well as ionic liquids, ammonium salt [23–25], noble metals (e.g., PdCl2 [26]) and lanthanide (e.g., Yb(OTf)3 [27]). However, major drawbacks have been noticed for these reported synthetic methods such as high reaction temperature [28–30], very long reaction time, and use of toxic or hazardous solvents and so on. Besides, most of the used catalysts are toxic, corrosive [31,32], expensive [26], non-recoverable, and provide low to moderate yields [33]. Alternatively, heterogeneous catalysts such as supported ionic liquids [34,35,30], Fe-Al/Cly [31], Nano-ZrO2 [28], SiO2-NaHSO4 [36], Fe3O4@mesoporous SBA-15 [32], Fe3O 4@SiO2–APTS–EDTA–As [37], ompg-C3N4/SO3H [38], 10 wt% Co/Al2O3 [39], Cu(II)-MOF [40], h-BN/Fe3O4/Co [41] and Cu@ Fe3O4@SiO2 [42] have been used to tackle some of the above-mentioned challenges. Due to the potential applications of DHPMs compounds, it is highly important to address these general drawbacks and improve the limitations of the existing catalytic systems by developing new and more effective alternatives. Due to increased awareness toward environmental pollution and the importance of sustainable and green chemistry. We are interested in synthesizing a new heterogeneous catalyst based on bismuth metal supported on chitosan as a catalytic support. Chitosan is a green, highly abundant, sustainable, and biodegradable biomaterial produced from seafood industry waste, thanks to the OH and NH2 groups present on its surface and their enriched reactivity [43]. In the past, chitosan has been used as catalyst on its own [44] or as a support to stabilize metal catalyst [45]. Although an exhaustive list of metals (e.g. palladium [46], copper [47,48], among others) supported on chitosan have already been reported for many catalytic reactions, bismuth supported on chitosan has been reported in only one case [49] but never used in the one-pot Biginelli condensation. Bismuth [50] was chosen because it is the least toxic heavy metal and has interesting redox properties [51] as well as Lewis acid character that allows it to efficiently activate carbonyls and dienes [52,53]. Prior to its entrapment, chitosan backbone was firstly functionalized with a phosphonium ionic liquid arms [54–58] through Schiff base condensation. Due to their stability and activity, ionic liquids have found many varied applications. For example, they have been used in the heterogeneous aerobic oxidative coupling of diaryl ether [59], the conversion of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone [60] and as catalysts in the oxidative coupling of benzene [61]. Phosphonium functions in particular have been incorporated into these liquids due to their use as catalysts in various chemical processes such as multi-condensation reaction, redox reaction, polymer synthesis, as well as their beneficial role in coordinating the outer sphere of the metal catalyst [62]. The preparation of Bismuth supported on chitosan grafted by phosphonium ionic liquid (CS@PIL@Bi) was carried through a two-step process. In the first step, chitosan was modified by grafting phosphonium ionic liquid (PIL) onto its free amino groups [43] followed by the fixation of Bi(III) ions via coordination bonds. The resulting materials were characterized by different spectroscopic and microscopic techniques such as FTIR and solid-state NMR spectroscopy, SEM, X-ray diffraction, ICP-MS, thermogravimetry. The resulting materials displayed excellent catalytic activity and recyclability for Biginelli condensation. Results and discussion Catalyst preparation and characterization The preparation of bismuth supported on chitosan@phosphonium ionic liquid CS@PIL@Bi was performed through the formation of Schiff base CS@PIL by chemical condensation of primary amine of chitosan with (formylmethyl)triphenyl phosphonium chloride (PIL) in methanol at 65 °C for 48 h, as reported in the literature (Scheme 1 ) [63–66]. The use of excess of PIL (4 equiv.) and long reaction time are essential for substantial functionalization on the majority of free-NH2 groups present on the chitosan surface, resulting in a yellow solid. Immerging the obtained Schiff base CS@PIL in a neutral solution of Bi(OTf)3/MeOH (30 mM) at room temperature for 48 h results in the formation of CS@PIL@Bi [see Supplementary Information S1 for more details]. The structural analysis of the chitosan backbone after modification by phosphonium ionic liquid (PIL) was performed using FTIR analysis (Fig. 1 a), with native chitosan (CS) serving as the reference. Upon modification of CS by PIL, the FTIR spectrum of CS@PIL (Schiff base) shows the appearance of three new peaks at 1550, 1450, and 748 cm−1, corresponding to ν(CN), ν(P+-C), and ν(CC)phenyl, respectively, with the simultaneous disappearance of ν(NH) at 1598 cm−1, confirming the formation of the Schiff base. However, it has been reported in the literature [63,66] that the vibrational range of the imine ν(CN) group is located between 1600–1640 cm−1 for chitosan modified by aromatic aldehydes. In our case, the shift of ν(CN) to the high vibrational values (1550 cm−1) can be explained by the presence of the phosphonium group. The formation of the imine function was further ascertained by a reduction reaction using NaBH4 in methanol at ambient temperature for 10 min (Scheme 1), leading to the bleaching of CS@PIL and the disappearance of the imine bond ν(CN) located towards 1500 cm−1 (CS@PIL (No Schiff base)) (Fig. 1b). The grafting of phosphonium on the chitosan support was confirmed by 31P solid NMR. The spectrum shows a singlet phosphorus peak at 20.31 ppm corresponding to the PIL supported on chitosan via imine bonds (Fig. 1e). A slight change was noticed for both FTIR and 31P NMR after Bi entrapment. Indeed, a shift of the imine bond ν(CN) from 1550 cm−1 to 1545 cm−1 was observed in the CS@PIL@Bi spectrum, which suggest an interplay of the metal with reactive groups located on the surface of chitosan. Similarly, the phosphorus peak shifted to lower values by 1.3 ppm, as shown in the spectrum (Fig. 1f). This shift can be attributed to the electron donation from phosphonium to the empty orbitals of Bi (1H and 13C, see Supplementary Information S1). The presence of crystalline bismuth was confirmed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, with the effect of ligand conjugation and metal immobilization on the structural reorganization of chitosan network being simultaneously investigated. Figure 1b shows the XRD patterns of native CS, CS@PIL and CS@PIL@Bi materials. CS was found to have an amorphous phase with two large peaks at 2θ values of 11.60° and 20.38°, attributed to the (020) and (100) reflections, respectively. Compared to pure CS, the CS@PIL pattern showed a small peak around the 2θ value of 21.64° adjacent to the amorphous CS phase, indicating the creation of small ordering probably through the packing of the newly introduced ligands within the network. The XRD spectrum of pure bismuth, as described in the literature, crystallizes under a rhombohedral symmetric phase, with characteristic peaks at 2θ values of 22.60°, 27.28°, 38.06°, 39.79°, 44.68°, 46.08°, 48.76°, 56.11°, 59.50°, 62.29°, 64.74°, 67.53°, 70.91°, and 72.08°, corresponding to the (003), (012), (104), (110), (015), (006), (202), (024), (107), (116), (122), (018), (214), and (300) reflections, respectively [67]. These peaks are well recognized in CS@PIL@Bi at 2θ values of 32.65°, 40.95°, 46.64°, 54.60°, and 58.5°, corresponding to the (012), (104), (110), (202), and (107) reflections, respectively. These results provide clear evidence for the presence of crystalline bismuth particles in the prepared catalyst. The surface morphology of the catalyst prepared in this study was analyzed using SEM spectroscopy. SEM images of CS, CS@PIL, and CS@PIL@Bi are presented in (Fig. 1c). Compared to neat CS, the two prepared catalysts exhibit significant differences in surface morphology. Neat CS shows a uniform structure without any particles on its surface, whereas the prepared catalysts show surface modifications for CS@PIL catalyst and the presence of supported particles on the surface for CS@PIL@Bi. Elemental analysis was also performed to confirm the presence of phosphorus, chlorine, and bismuth in these materials. Figure 1d shows the EDS analysis of pure CS and the prepared catalysts, which indicates the presence of two signals of phosphorus at 2.01 keV and chlorine at 2.68 keV in the product CS@PIL. This confirms the grafting of the phosphonium arm onto the chitosan, and a signal located between 2.3 and 2.5 keV indicates the presence of elemental bismuth in the material CS@PIL@Bi after its coordination with CS@PIL. Additionally, other elements such as carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen were also observed in the EDS spectrum, which can be attributed to the different functional groups present in CS. The amount of bismuth contained per gram of prepared catalyst dissolved in aqueous acetic acid was calculated by ICP-MS and found to be 910 µg (See Supplementary Information for more details). Catalysis Catalytic activity As mentioned earlier, our study focuses on efficacy evaluation of the novel CS@PIL@Bi synthesized catalyst toward the Biginelli condensation, this latter selected as a model reaction. This reaction reduces both the time and energy consumption while minimizing harmful waste production, and it also leads to the production of DHPMs, which are of strong therapeutic and pharmaceutical biological interest. The reaction involves the condensation of three components: derivatives of benzaldehyde, β-ketoester, and urea/thiourea. Therefore, we are particularly interested in catalyzing the condensation of benzaldehyde derivatives, ethyl acetoacetate, and urea using our synthesized catalysts as shown in Scheme 2 . CS-supported bismuth catalysts have been investigated in various experimental conditions, including neat or solvent diluted reactions, heating or at room temperature or heated procedures, and in the presence or absence of various bases (e.g., NaOH, KOH, K2CO3), in both Bi0 metallic (CS-BiNPs) and cationic (CS-Bi) forms [49]. However, no reaction was observed under these heterogeneous conditions, likely because of the presence of free amino groups (NH2) on the chitosan backbone, that compete with the urea and reduce selectivity. To address this issue, we propose a prior functionalization of the amino groups of CS using benzaldehyde (Bn) to prevent the competitive reaction and improve selectivity through stronger coordination with bismuth Schiff base formed. The CS amino groups were functionalized with Bn in methanol at 60 °C for 48 h, followed by coordination with bismuth (III) in a neutral medium of Bi(OTf)3 in methanol. The synthesized catalyst CS-Bn@Bi was tested in a model Biginelli condensation reaction using acetonitrile as the solvent at 80 °C for 4 h. Although the reaction produced the desired product, 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one (DHPM), the yields and conversions were low (40%), indicating suboptimal performance. Nevertheless, this outcome confirmed the importance of protecting the amines present on chitosan during the synthesis process. Previous studies have demonstrated that ionic liquids, such as quaternary ammonium, can catalyze the Biginelli condensation reaction due to their Bronsted acid properties [23,24,34]. We consequently attempted chitosan (CS) conjugation with an aldehyde-containing ionic liquid arm. This modification led to the formation of a CS@PIL Schiff base, which trapped Bi3+ ions through coordination interaction to create the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst (Scheme 1). The presence of two active species, phosphonium and Bi, on the CS support is expected to synergistically improve the catalytic reactivity of the reaction. Initially, we tested the CS@PIL Schiff base catalyst under the same conditions as the Biginelli condensation reaction, using acetonitrile as the solvent and in the absence of a base at 80 °C. This reaction resulted in the formation of the desired DHPM product with an observed conversion rate of 60% after 16 h of reaction. This conversion rate was attributed to the activity of the phosphonium arm, which also increased the selectivity of the reaction by blocking the -NH2 groups of chitosan. We then tested the influence of bismuth immobilized on same support CS@PIL@Bi, and the combination of these two phosphonium and metal catalysts effectively led to the formation of DHPM products with conversion between 75–100% (Table 1 ) in reaction times not exceeding 4 h (Scheme 3 ). Thus, CS@PIL@Bi catalyst showed the potential to be a highly efficient and selective catalyst for the Biginelli condensation. The efficiency of the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst was evaluated by using various benzaldehyde derivatives to compare the influence of steric and electronic effects on the conversion and yield of the reaction. Table 1 summarizes the precursors used and compares the results obtained with benzaldehyde as a reference (Entry 1). It was observed that the insertion of an electron-donor or electron-withdrawing group improved the yield of the reaction, with a slight reduction when the reagent was substituted by a bromine atom in ortho- and meta-positions or an acid function in the para-position (Entries 9, 10, and 12, with 75–97% conversion and 65–68% yield). In the presence of phenol derivatives (Entries 2 and 3), the yield increased from 81% to 88% in the ortho- and para-positions, respectively, due to steric effects. Similar results were observed with bromine substitution in the ortho-position (Entries 9 to 11 with 65% to 86% yields). In the presence of chlorine versus hydroxyl groups (Entries 4 and 5), the yield increased from 80% to 92%, respectively, in favor of two halide atoms, proving the influence of the electronic donor effect of the substituents. The obtained turnover number (TON), calculated as the molar quantity of product obtained divided by the molar quantity of catalyst used, was 6184. Catalyst recyclability Recycling is a key goal in heterogeneous catalysis. However, the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst displays weak non-covalent bonds between bismuth metal and the support that may cause bismuth release into the reaction medium, hindering the catalyst recycling. Accordingly, dedicated tests were performed to confirm the absence of metal leaching (see Supplementary Information S2). After only 2 h of reaction, the catalyst was removed by filtration, and the obtained catalyst free mixture, was allowed to react further. In these conditions, no time-dependent mixture composition changes were observed, indicating that bismuth was not released into the reaction mixture and strongly remained on the CS@PIL support. The catalytic recyclability of the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst was evaluated over five cycles, displaying any loss of catalytic efficiency and achieving 100% reaction conversion (see Supplementary Information S2). Beyond five cycles, the catalyst's efficiency decreased by 2% to 10% (conversion) over eight cycles (Fig. 2 ). Therefore, the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst demonstrates excellent recyclability. Compared to conventional catalysts for the Biginelli condensation, the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst offers several advantages. It is derived from nontoxic, non-corrosive, and cost-effective biobased precursors, and it can catalyze the reaction within a short time of only 4 h, providing yields ranging from 65–94%. In contrast, other methods used in the condensation process often have limitations such as the use of high temperatures (Entries 2 to 6 and 8, Table 2 ), prolonged reaction times (Entries 1 and 8, Table 2), low or moderate yields, toxic or hazardous solvents, and large amounts of catalyst. Moreover, many of these catalysts are toxic, corrosive, expensive, and non-recoverable. Table 2 presents some examples of catalysts reported in the literature. Catalyst stability The stability of heterogeneous catalysts is a critical factor that significantly affects the outcome of chemical reactions. The stability of the catalyst depends on multiple factors, including its chemical composition, surface area, and reaction conditions. We found that the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst retained its efficiency without significant loss of performance after five cycles of use. However, to determine the cause of its subsequent decline (cycles 6 to 8), we characterized the catalyst after the sixth cycle of use. FTIR analysis revealed that the imine function of the catalyst (CN) remained stable, but we observed aldehyde uptake due to the appearance of aldehydic (CH) proton bonds and aromatic (CC) and (CH) bonds (Fig. 3 a). In addition, SEM analysis of the catalyst used after six cycles showed the partial leaching of the bismuth particles that were initially supported on the surface of catalyst (Fig. 3c). This was confirmed by the decrease in the amount of supported bismuth using EDS mapping (Fig. 3d). The ICP analysis confirmed the leaching of bismuth metal by 550 µg.g−1 (a 39.57% decrease), which led to the loss of catalyst efficiency after cycle 5. The TGA analysis of the catalysts before and after use showed similar thermal stability for the catalysts before and after use (Fig. 3b). Interestingly, no bismuth was detected by EDS in the synthesized DHPM (see Supplementary Information S2). These results highlight the importance of understanding the stability of heterogeneous catalysts and the need to develop strategies to prevent their degradation to maintain their efficiency over multiple cycles. Proposed mechanism Based on the results reported in the literature [21,22,41,42], we suggest a plausible mechanistic pathway for the synthesis of DHPMs, as illustrated in Scheme 4 . Initially, urea undergoes nucleophilic addition to aldehydes activated by Bismuth and Phosphonium. The presence of alcohol (OH) groups on the chitosan surface increases the catalytic activity by activating carbonyl groups via hydrogen bonds, leading to dehydration and formation of acylimine (A). This intermediate undergoes nucleophilic attack by the β-dicarbonyl ester enolate to generate an open-chain ureide (B). The intermediate B then undergoes cyclization and loses one molecule of water to yield the target product with regeneration of the catalyst. Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a highly efficient and sustainable heterogeneous catalyst, CS@PIL@Bi, based on cost-effective and biosourced materials. The catalyst demonstrated outstanding catalytic activity, as evidenced by the successful synthesis of various DHPM derivatives through a one-pot Biginelli condensation reaction. This green catalyst has great potential for use in other condensation reactions that require high catalytic activity. Additionally, the CS@PIL@Bi catalyst showed good recyclability, with only a minor decrease in efficiency after six uses. This can significantly reduce the amount of waste generated during chemical processes, making it a more sustainable synthetic approach. The catalyst's heterogeneous nature also makes it easy to separate from the reaction mixture, providing another significant advantage. Thus, CS@PIL@Bi catalyst is a superior alternative to other heterogeneous catalysts described in the literature and a promising candidate for large-scale applications in green chemistry. Overall, this study provides a valuable contribution to the development of sustainable and efficient catalysts for green chemistry applications. Experimental section Materials and method The chemicals used in this work were purchased in various suppliers: chitosan (molecular weight 100 000–300 000 and DDP = 80%, 5.9 mmol.g−1) from Acros Organics, (formylmethyl)triphenylphosphonium chloride, Bi(OTf)3, Urea, Ethyl acetoacetate, all aldehyde derivatives from Sigma-Aldrich, 2-bromobenzaldehyde, 3-bromobenzaldehyde, 4-bromobenzaldehyde and 2-hydroxy-4-méthoxybenzaldehyde from Alfa-Aesar. Methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), acetonitrile (CH3CN), ethyl acetate (AcOEt), technical solvents CH2Cl2 (DCM), hexane, and NMR solvents (CDCl3 and DMSO-d6), were purchased from Sigma Aldrich.1H and 13C Spectra using CDCl3 and DMSO-d6 solvents were acquired on a Burker Elmer (400 Hz) and (300 Hz). SEM-microscopy type Tescan Vega3 scanning electron microscope was coupled to an energy dispersive. The X-ray diffraction analyses were performed on a Rigaku diffractometer ``SmartLab''. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were determined on KBr using a spectrometer type (Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100) over a range of 450 to 4000 cm−1. General protocol Catalyst synthesis The synthesis of the catalyst was performed in two steps by reacting (300 mg 1.76 mmol) of chitosan (CS) and (2.4 g, 7.04 mmol) of (formylmethyl)triphenylphosphonium chloride (PIL) in methanol at 65 °C for 48 h. After cooling at room temperature, the yellow solid was filtered and washed several times with methanol to eliminate the free (formylmethyl)triphenylphosphonium chloride (PIL). The solid was dried at 40 °C under vacuum for 5 h. After drying, the CS@PIL was immersed in a neutral solution of Bi(OTf)3 at 30 mM in methanol for 48 h at room temperature. The CS@PIL@Bi catalyst was filtered and washed several times with methanol and dried at 40 °C for 12 h under vacuum. Catalysis 2.50 mmol of aldehyde derivatives, 2.50 mmol of ethyl acetoacetate and 35 mg of CS@PIL@Bi catalyst (0.091 wt% Bi continent) were added on a solution of urea (3.10 mmol) in 10 ml of acetonitrile (CH3CN). The reaction mixture was heated at 80 °C for 4 h. The progress of the reactions was monitored by TLC analysis. The crude product was cooled to room temperature. Acetonitrile was removed in vacuo and the solid residue was dissolved in 15 ml of hot ethyl acetate-ethanol (1:1 V/V) to recover the catalyst by filtration. After solvent evaporation, the recovered solid was washed with water and recrystallized in ethanol. coredata.dc:description: An easy synthesis of a novel solid catalyst based on chitosan grafted with phosphonium ionic liquid (CS@PIL) supporting bismuth (Bi) was carried out through a two-step process. In the first step, chitosan was modified with phosphonium ionic liquid (PIL), and in the second step, Bi(III) ions were coordinated to the chelating groups on the solid support. The resulting materials were characterized using various techniques, including FTIR and solid-state NMR spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction, ICP-MS, and thermogravimetry. It was found that the desired products of Biginelli condensation couldn't be obtained when Bi(III) was supported on native chitosan due to the reactivity of its NH2 groups with the aldehyde reactant In turn, the modified CS@PIL@Bi catalyst exhibited remarkable efficiency and recyclability as a heterogeneous catalyst in the one-step Pietro Biginelli condensation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Bismuth supported on phosphonium functionalized chitosan as sustainable heterogeneous catalysts for one-pot Biginelli condensation
